channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Test of Faith in Brutal Captivity
item.description: After some of James Foley’s fellow Roman Catholics portrayed him as a symbol of faith under brutal conditions, the disclosure that he had converted to Islam in captivity has stirred debate.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Foley outside Aleppo, Syria, in July 2012, a few months before his abduction. After being kidnapped in Libya in 2011, he spoke about his Christian faith.

item.title: Old India’s Village of Warriors Becomes Birthplace of Bouncers
item.description: There are few places where historical periods slam into each other quite so forcefully as they do outside New Delhi, where musclemen whose ancestors fought invaders now defend bar patrons.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Men working out in Fatehpur Beri in the Delhi region. Many have jobs as bouncers in local clubs.

item.title: World Briefing: United Arab Emirates: Police Investigate Deadly Fire
item.description: The police in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates, are investigating a fire that tore through a building in an industrial area where laborers were sleeping and killed 10 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Singapore: Nation’s First Prime Minister Is Hospitalized
item.description: Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore’s first prime minister, has been hospitalized for severe pneumonia, the prime minister’s office said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Sudan: Gunmen Kidnap 89 Boys, Unicef Says
item.description: An armed group in South Sudan has abducted at least 89 boys in a northern state, the United Nations children’s agency said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Bank Workers Looted Bank, Official Says
item.description: Employees at a branch of Afghanistan’s central bank in Kandahar Province might have got away with as much as $1.4 million when they robbed their own bank, an official said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Polluted Air Cuts Years Off Lives of Millions in India, Study Finds
item.description: Altogether, 660 million Indians could lose 2.1 billion years in life expectancy as a result of air pollution, at enormous cost to the country’s economy, researchers found.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Kerry Raises Prospect of More Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine
item.description: At the start of a meeting with the British foreign secretary, Secretary of State John Kerry said Moscow had violated a cease-fire agreement.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Disclosures of Battle Plan by Pentagon Startle Many
item.description: A senior official told reporters that Iraqi and Kurdish forces, with help from the United States, were preparing to launch an assault to retake the Iraqi city of Mosul in April or May.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Concern in Britain as Schoolgirls Seek to Join Islamic State
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron said that the authorities would do everything they could to help the three teenagers, who were believed to be traveling to Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: News Analysis: A Deal That Preserves Greece’s Place in Eurozone, and Fiscal Restraints
item.description: An agreement to extend Greece’s bailout for four months also committed the nation to fiscal targets and other conditions that its new leadership had vowed to scrap.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Yemen’s Former Leader, Held by Rebels, Leaves Capital
item.description: President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi left the capital on Saturday amid conflicting reports about whether he was released voluntarily or had escaped from his Houthi captors.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, who resigned as Yemen's president last month, in 2014.

item.title: U.S. Open to Slowing Troop Pullout in Afghanistan
item.description: The 10,000 American troops are now conducting counterterrorism operations and advising the Afghan military, and most are scheduled to be withdrawn by the end of 2016.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Ashton B. Carter, left, with President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan.

item.title: Venezuela Mayor Is Accused of U.S.-Backed Coup Plot
item.description: Mayor Antonio Ledezma of Caracas, indicted on charges of conspiracy and plotting a coup, was to be moved to a military prison outside the capital, the government said.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By GIRISH GUPTA
item.media:description: A protester held a poster of Mayor Antonio Ledezma and chains on Friday in Caracas.

item.title: Battle to Retake Iraqi City Looms as Test of Obama’s ISIS Strategy
item.description: American intelligence agencies and the Pentagon are struggling to determine how difficult it will be to retake Mosul, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in Iraq, as planning intensifies for a battle there.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Emrah Yorulmaz/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga forces north of Mosul last month. Reclaiming the city will require up to 25,000 Iraqi and Kurdish troops.

item.title: Somali Deaths Climb to 25 In Hotel Attack
item.description: The Shabab, a rebel group, claimed responsibility for the attack on Friday, which targeted government ministers and lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Emergency workers carried away a survivor from a blast that killed 10 people at the Central Hotel in Mogadishu, Somalia on Friday.

item.title: Ashton Carter, Defense Secretary, in Afghanistan for Security Talks
item.description: Four days after he was sworn in, Mr. Carter arrived on Saturday in Afghanistan to meet with senior American and Afghan officials and make his own assessment of the security situation.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Apartment Tower Fire in Dubai Is Put Out
item.description: No injuries were reported at the Torch, an 86-story residential building in the skyscraper-packed Marina district of the Gulf emirate.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Canada Attack Suspect Is Now Charged in 3 Killings
item.description: Ian Bush, a human resources manager from suburban Ottawa who was arrested in December in an attack on a 101-year-old veteran, is now accused of murdering three people in 2007
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Judge Orders Stop to Detention of Families at Borders
item.description: A federal judge ruled that the Obama administration must stop holding women and children caught trying to enter the country illegally whether or not they had applied for asylum.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
